subject: RE: [junit] displaying multiple errors from the same condition

Many wonderful things are in Java 5 that weren't available before.
However, Collections.EMPTY_LIST is not one of those things.  It's been
around since 1.2 I believe (it's certainly there in 1.4--I use it all
the time).

________________________________

From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
James Abley
Sent: Thursday, December 01, 2005 3:24 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] displaying multiple errors from the same condition


On 30/11/05, J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains@...> wrote:
>
>  Chris Dollin wrote:
> > On Tuesday 29 November 2005 18:32, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> >
> >  > The short answer: there is a way to make JUnit do this, but many
of
> us
> >  > don't like to do it that way. For a test like this, I might do
the
> >  > following:
> >  >
> >  > List failedUrls = new ArrayList();
> >  > foreach (URL url : urlsToTest) {
> >  >      if (failed(url)) {
> >  >          failedUrls.add(url);
> >  >      }
> >  > }
> >  > assertTrue(failedUrls.isEmpty());
> >
> > I would use
> >
> >     assertEquals( new ArrayList(), failedUrls );
> >
> > [and might well have a constant `emptyList` around], on the grounds
> > that when the Unfortunate Event of test failure occurs the default
> > failure message of assertEquals will tell me which URLs failed.
>
> :)
>
> Everyone thinks I'm a little slow today.
>
> By the way, the "emptyList" constant already exists:
> Collections.EMPTY_LIST.


Only since Java 5 though; some of us still have to produce code which
works
with earlier versions of Java!
